main event: On March 6, 1951, in Albuquerque, New Mexico, there was a report of a very bright object crossing the sky, which was observed by four Los Alamos personnel and two Kirtland AFB pilots. The object was reported as a meteor by the pilots and was later described by Dr. La Paz as a detonating fireball, with no fragments recovered.
interesting points: The report gathered by Domestic Intelligence suggested a possible attempted recovery of portions assumed to have landed from the object.
The document recommended photographic coverage of the area to search for remnants of the fireball.
There were previous incidents of anomalous luminous phenomena occurring in northeastern New Mexico and adjacent portions of Texas and Colorado.
Despite the extensive search, no meteoritic fragments were recovered, raising questions about the nature of the object.
The recommendation to conduct ground searches in the area where meteoritic ingress occurred based on the possibility of substantial damage and effects.
result: The object was initially reported as a meteor, but the lack of recovered fragments raised doubts about its true nature, leaving the event unexplained.
sighted object: very bright object crossing the sky
witnesses: four Los Alamos personnel and two Kirtland AFB pilots
